discussion.content:
White-listing is correct.

Only parts of the application are not running meaning that they want the application to be able to run because other parts of the application are already running.

If they didn't want it to run, it would've been black listed.

Now, to allow the application to run properly, they admin needs to finish what was started, and white-list the parts of the application that it needs to function.

The problem starts out saying a number of employees. It's not all employees. So, why are only a subset having a problem? If I were to minimize risk and attack exposure, I'd want to first investigate the problematic DLLs on those workstations first, and therefore, I lean towards "B".

comments.content: If it’s only part of users then why would you suspect file integrity ?

discussion.content: those are 2 Dll files are libraries and by implementing whitelisting will reduce the risk in those libraries.
C. Since it stated to resolve the issue.

How could whitelist minimize risk and attack exposure? If these two DLL files are already compromised, then whitelist the affected libraries will introduce a huge risk. I understand whitelist is a way to resolve this issue. but the integrity of the DLL files should be checked first.

I so lost But getting small ideas from here
Thank u all

comments.content: Thank you all for spreading confusion

discussion.content:
Enterprise resource planning (ERP) is defined as the ability to deliver an integrated suite of business applications. ERP tools share a common process and data model, covering broad and deep operational end-to-end processes, such as those found in finance, HR, distribution, manufacturing, service and the supply chain.
These libraries are apt and need to whitelisted

comments.content: Yes but still, to minimize the risk , I would check their integrity before whitelisting. Question unfortunately asks for "resolution" and whitelisting is the only way

discussion.content: The answer is correct because by Whitelisting these financemodule.dll the os will trust this module and will run it with out issue here the os think that the user need admin permission to run dll file.

The question states "BEST resolve this issue while minimizing risk and attack exposure". Resolving the issue which is "parts of an ERP application (finance module and general ledger) are not working" can only be with whitelisting the affected libraries that are not permitted to execute.

comments.content: I mean, if you only verify the DLL's file integrity but not allow permission to execute the libraries, you are not resolving the issue.

discussion.content:
I was leaning towards C, but I saw the question says to “minimise risk and attack exposure”. Whitelisting the libraries fixes the issue but it definitely doesn’t meet this. Especially if the dlls have been compromised.
Verifying file integrity definitely is a great starting point to reduce risk, after we have confirmed all is ok we can whitelist the dlls.

comments.content: Resolve the issue to minimize risk and attack exposure is the complete last part.

discussion.content: u would do b, but to resolve issue C is needed. so C

B The question doesn’t say “parts of a new ERP application”. So we assume it’s not a new app. The DLLs may have been replaced with hacker’s code, so when users tried to execute them, the executables got “permission denied.” In that case, you would need to verify the file integrity (compare hashes) to determine if the code had been replaced.
B “While” means “both” – like BOTH resolve the issue AND minimize the risk. Since you need to do BOTH, then start with the integrity checks.
its B mo said so and hes doctor
Wouldn't you want to verify the hash first before whitelisting the DLL's?

comments.content: Sure but that doesn’t resolve it

questions.question_text:
A number of employees report that parts of an ERP application are not working. The systems administrator reviews the following information from one of the employee workstations:
Execute permission denied: financemodule.dll
Execute permission denied: generalledger.dll
Which of the following should the administrator implement to BEST resolve this issue while minimizing risk and attack exposure?

choices.D: Place the affected employees in the local administrator's group

questions.question_text:
A security analyst receives a notification from the IDS after working hours, indicating a spike in network traffic. Which of the following BEST describes this type of
IDS?

discussion.content: Anomaly-based detection is the process of comparing definitions of what activity is considered normal against observed events to identify significant deviations.

Network Intrusion Detection: Anomaly Based
Anomaly-based detection generally needs to work on a statistically significant number of packets, because any packet is only an anomaly compared to some baseline. This need for a baseline presents several difficulties. For one, anomaly-based detection will not be able to detect attacks that can be executed with a few or even a single packet. These attacks, such as the ping of death, do still exist [32], and are

While signature-based detection compares behavior to rules, anomaly-based detection compares behavior to profiles [1]. These profiles still need to define what is normal, like rules need to be defined. However, anomaly-based profiles are more like white lists, because the profile detects when behavior goes outside an acceptable range.
Key: "After Working Hours"

comments.content: No ... spike in traffic. Deviation from baseline obviosly after hours lol
Yes, deviations from a pattern of normal network traffic.

questions.question_text: An instructor is teaching a hands-on wireless security class and needs to configure a test access point to show students an attack on a weak protocol. Which of the following configurations should the instructor implement?

discussion.content:
This question was on the test. Taken Jan 24, 2020 
Provided answer is correct.

comments.content: Damn you took the test before COVID

discussion.content: WEP=WEakProtocol
WEP is considered to be one of the more vulnerable security protocols.

WEP is a security algorithm for wireless networks. It's intention was to provide data confidentiality comparable to that of a traditional wired network.
Correct answer: D

But WEP is for wired equivalent
 protection not wireless

comments.content: "Wired Equivalent Privacy (WEP) is a security protocol, specified in the IEEE Wireless Fidelity (Wi-Fi) standard, 802.11b, that is designed to provide a wireless local area network (WLAN) with a level of security and privacy comparable to what is usually expected of a wired LAN."
I agree with you. I would go with A & E.

discussion.content: Should be E and A, WPA2-PSK doesn't use EAP-TLS.

Counter Mode with Cipher Block Chaining Message Authentication Code Protocol (CCMP) is an encryption protocol that forms part of the 802.11i standard for wireless local area networks (WLANs), particularly those using WiMax technology. The CCMP algorithm is based on the U.S. federal government's Advanced Encryption Standard (AES).
WPA-PSK is pre-shared key, it can't provide accounting (in AAA) as everyone will have the same key. It has to be TKIP and 802.1X. Please explain if I am wrong.
Vote for AE
Which one is correct?

questions.question_text:
A security analyst is hardening a large-scale wireless network. The primary requirements are the following:
✑ Must use authentication through EAP-TLS certificates
✑ Must use an AAA server
✑ Must use the most secure encryption protocol
Given these requirements, which of the following should the analyst implement and recommend? (Choose two.)

A company recently experienced data exfiltration via the corporate network. In response to the breach, a security analyst recommends deploying an out-of-band
IDS solution. The analyst says the solution can be implemented without purchasing any additional network hardware. Which of the following solutions will be used to deploy the IDS?

discussion.content:
This question was on the test. Taken Jan 24, 2020 
Provided answer is correct. Key word in the question is, "without purchasing any additional network hardware", assuming the network obviously have switches, but no Network TAP (Test Access Point) device. 
""A network tap is an external monitoring device that mirrors the traffic that passes between two network nodes.""

D.
Port Mirroring, also known as SPAN (Switched Port Analyzer), is a method of monitoring network traffic. With port mirroring enabled, the switch sends a copy of all network packets seen on one port (or an entire VLAN) to another port, where the packet can be analyzed.

It is D: Port Mirroring (John Dion's Exam Notes) 
 One or more switch ports are configured to forward all of their packets to 
another port on the switch or If you cannot configure a SPAN port, then you can use a network tap 
Network Tap
• A physical device that allows you to intercept the traffic between 
two points on the network
port mirroring is the cost effective solution
Two ways for IDS - inline or TAP and passive or out of band. Port mirroring via switch will send a copy of the packet to the IDS.
Is this A or D, please?

comments.content:
I think the answer is D.
Since we are not purchasing additional hardware, we can rule out D. A network TAP is a hardware component that connects into the cabling infrastructure to copy packets for monitoring purposes.
